Exit polls show Blundell and Rowley in fight for Presidency

Nouse and YUSU exit polls see Lydia Blundell and Charlie Rowley in battle for Presidency (Thumbnail credit Credit: Pete Iveson. YUSU Presidents at their Hustings night)

York Sport candidates top recognition poll

A recent <em>Nouse</em> election poll has shown that the race for York Sport Presidency have been the most visible so far, with both Asfahani and McGladdery ranking in the top four most recognised candidates (Thumbnail credit York Sport candidates McGladdery and Asfahani have caught the attention of the student body. Image credit: Peter Iveson)

Ziggys evacuation sparks YUSU enquiry

YUSU have confirmed they have launched an investigation after the popular student nightclub Ziggy's was evacuated this Wednesday, following the detonation of a smoke grenade (Thumbnail credit Students gathered outside of Ziggys after being evacuated. Image credit: Rose Troup-Buchanan)

Mass controversy over visiting Islamic scholar

The invitation of Islamic Scholar Mufti Muhammad ibn Adam al-Kawthari to speak at the University on Wednesday has sparked controversy across campus (Thumbnail credit Mufti Muhammad ibn Adam al-Kawthari delivering a lecture)

YUSU election candidates revealed

The full list of candidates standing in this year's YUSU elections has been released

Council discriminate against students in housing policy

By James Bithell

York's student resident population has been caught up in a political decision which will force rents to rise and discriminate against students attempting to find off-campus housing (Thumbnail credit Data compiled by Nouse from Council records show popular student roads which may suffer the worst rent rises. Graphic: Jonathan Frost)

University to assist with "hidden costs"

Details have recently come to light of the proposed changes to be introduced by the University after the tuition fee increase is implemented (Thumbnail credit If University of York tuition fees are put up to PS9,000 in 2012, each student could be given a free laptop. Photo: Justyn Hardcastle)

Internship company criticised for illicitly recruiting students in lectures

The American internship company, Southwestern, has come under pressure after inappropriately recruiting potential students for their summer internship programme in lectures (Thumbnail credit The Southwestern internship programme have been recruiting in lectures without Departmental permission. Photo: University of York)

Flooded rooms causes disruption for students

Students living in Eric Milner, Block A have voiced their disapprovement with the conditions of their accommodation after three rooms and a main hallway have been flooded (Thumbnail credit James Block N has been without laundry along with Eric Milner Block A. Photo: Peter Iveson)

Fusion question charity law

The society Fusion has been told they will be unable to give the proceeds from the ticket sales of this year's event to charity (Thumbnail credit Fusion are attempting to donate profits from the show to charity. Photo: Fusion)

Budget miscalculations delay Heslington East

Work on the Social and Catering building on Heslington East is to be put on hold for over a year (Thumbnail credit Image: University of York)

York to admit 450 more students than projected

Figures have revealed that the University have over-subscribed 400 more students to study at York next year than projections made in 2009 (Thumbnail credit Graphic: Jonathan Frost)

Voting for Vanbrugh by-elections disrupted

Members of Vanbrugh College were unable to vote for three days in their JCRC by-elections that took place last week (Thumbnail credit Vanbrugh students have had problems voting on the YUSU website for the unfilled JCRC positions. Photo: Vanbrugh)

Popular bar Los Locos closed after difficulties

Los Locos, a TEXMEX restaurant and bar in Micklegate, was shut down earlier this week and is not expected to reopen (Thumbnail credit The bar had links with Colleges. Photo: Facebook)

First RAG jailbreak fails to attract sufficient interest

An attempt to organise a University of York 'jailbreak' was unsuccessful as last weekend's event was cancelled due to a lack of participants (Thumbnail credit RAG events carry on this week. Photo: Facebook)

Union General Meeting sees highest voting numbers since 2008

All six motions have been passed from last week's UGM, with the highest voting turnout since January 2008 of 1592 voters

Aaron Porter: on fees and failures

NUS President Aaron Porter talks to Martin Spurr about student protests and recent calls for his resignation (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: NUS)

PS50,000 salary increase for Vice-Chancellor since 2008

It has been revealed that the University of York Vice-Chancellor, Brian Cantor, has benefited from a 24 per cent salary rise over the last three years (Thumbnail credit As Vice-Chancellor, Brian Cantor is a global figurehead for the University. Photo credit: Georgie Mabee)

Renewed calls for closure of B-Henrys

B-Henrys, the Alcuin College bar, is facing closure as students continue to favour to go straight into the city on nights out (Thumbnail credit The Alcuin College bar, B-Henry's, is facing renewed calls for closure due to ongoing profit losses. Photo credit: George Lowther)

York Chancellor calls for local TV in the city

Greg Dyke, Chancellor of the University of York, has suggested that York would be the ideal city in which to set up a local television channel

Larger workshops replacing first-year seminars divides English Department

The English Department's Board of Studies will continue using workshops instead of half the number of undergraduate seminars (Thumbnail credit English course reps voted to continue with workshops, despite opposition)

Student parent needs not met by University

Concerns been raised over the lack of University provisions for both undergraduate and postgraduate student parents (Thumbnail credit The waiting lists for the York Campus nursery can be up to two years. Photo credit: George Lowther)

YUSU Officers propose major overhaul of democratic structure

Camilla Apcar looks at the proposed future of YUSU's Democratic Structure, which will be put to a cross-campus vote after tomorrow's Union General Meeting (Thumbnail credit Walker: last Democracy Sabb?)

Is Dr Dre coming to York?

A group of students are attempting to mandate YUSU to ensure that the American artist, Dr Dre, play at Central Hall (Thumbnail credit One of the campaign posters on the Facebook group for Dr Dre. Image credit: Facebook campaign group: 'Want Dr Dre in York')

York to weather budget cuts

The effects of the upcoming Higher Education cuts to the University of York teaching budget may not be as drastic as originally predicted (Thumbnail credit University officials have an optimistic outlook despite cuts. Photo credit: George Lowther)

Colleges unable to fill major JCRC positions

The college Junior Common Room Committees (JCRCs) have faced widespread problems with filling all positions within each Committee

Student house prices continue to soar

Students are facing higher accommodation prices for next year as many landlords are increasing house prices across the city (Thumbnail credit Students living in popular areas, such as Heslington Road, will face annual rent increases up to PS250. Photo credit: Lucy Dixon)

University may charge single fee for all subjects from 2012

Senior figures within the University and YUSU have indicated a strong preference for a set fee across all courses at York, starting from when the government removes the tuition fee cap in 2012
